This 'book' has been created in a Glow Blog using the H5P plugin. It was made to show a few of the features of an H5P Iinteractive Book.

Glow Blogs are WordPress blogs that let you create both private and public facing websites and blogs.

A blog is is easy to keep up to date without any knowledge of programming in a web broswer.

Glow Blogs are used for School Websites, class blogs, project sites, e-Portfolios and a whole lot more.

params.text:
Did you know Glow Blogs run on WordPress the most popular way to create content on the web!

WordPress (WP or WordPress.org) is a web content management system. It was originally created as a tool to publish blogs but has evolved to support publishing other web content, including more traditional websites, mailing lists and Internet fora, media galleries, membership sites, learning management systems and online stores. Available as free and open-source software, WordPress is among the most popular content management systems – it was used by 42.8% of the top 10 million websites as of October 2021

params.text:
Do you know what Glow is?

Glow is Scotland’s nationally available digital environment to support learning across the whole curriculum. A Glow account provides access anytime and anywhere to a number of different web services on any device.

Funded by the Scottish Government and managed by Education Scotland, Glow provides a safer online environment for educators and learners to communicate and collaborate using the following services: Microsoft 365, Google Workspace for Education, Glow Login and Launch Pad and Glow Blogs.

About Glow - Glow Connect

params.text:
Do you know the basics to get you started?

A blog or site is a complete website. It is generally made up of several components.

  1. Posts & Pages which hold and organise content.
  2. Menus, which provide navigation.
  3. Widgets, which allow you to add extra content. 

In addition blogs support a multitude of different tyles of content, but the above list covers the basics.

Posts and pages provide the content for your site.

Both are made up of one or more of the following: A title, text, images and other media.

The main difference between posts and pages is that:

  • Posts are organised in reverse chronological order and pages are not. 
  • Post can be show as a list, on a home page, category or archive page. Pages are show individually.
  • Posts can also be tagged and categorised, pages can be organised hierarchically.

This can be confusing as a webpage may consist of a blog post. 

Posts and pages are created and edited largely in the same way. On the main Help Blog you can find out how to Create a Post and more about Pages.

Menus are the standard way to provide visitor a way of seeing the content of your site and allowing them to move around. Menus can be displayed in your themes menu bar.

A navigation menu is a list of a links. They are usually shown as a horizontal bar of links at the top of every page on a site.

Menus are one of the main ways to create site structure and allow visitors to find their way about the site.

Find out more about menus on the Help Blog.

Widgets are used to add content, features and functionality to the sidebar (usually) of your blog. Widget placement is dependent on themes.

Widgets are useful as they can display on every page and post of a selection of pages and posts. the is general help Widgets on Glow Blog Help along with examples of many of the widgets. The Jetpack plugin adds more widgets if it is activated and the Extra Sidebar Widget module is turned on. More information: Extra Sidebar Widgets – Jetpack.

Widgets can be displayed on pages and posts if you are using the Block Editor or  Make Theme.

params.textField:
Posts and pages provide the *content* for your site.

Both are made up of one or more of the following: A *title*, text, images and other media.

The main difference between posts and pages is that:

Posts are organised in reverse *chronological* order and pages are not. 
Post can be shown as a list, on a home page, category or archive page. Pages are shown *individually*.
Posts can also be tagged and *categorised*, pages can be organised hierarchically.
This can be confusing as a webpage may consist of a single blog post or page or a list of posts. 

Posts and pages are created and *edited* largely in the same way.

params.text:
Did you know it is really easy to create content on your site?

Most content in a Glow Blog site is held in a post or a page. The simplest post consists of a title and some body text.

Once you have a site set up it is easy to add content. 

  1. logon
  2. Click new post
  3. Type a title
  4. Type some content
  5. Click publish

you now have new content on your site. 

The could be augmented with images and all sorts of other content. Some of that content could be hosted on the site or other could be embedded from elsewhere.

Blogs can hold a vast array of different content. The 'book' you are reading was created on this blog with the H5P plugin.
A Post's title will appear anywhere that the post is listed.

Enter the text for your post. There are two modes of editing: Visual and Text. Choose the mode by clicking on the appropriate tab.

Visual mode gives you an editor that is similar to a word processor.You can insert media files by clicking the button above the post editor and following the directions.

You can align or edit images using the inline formatting toolbar available in Visual mode.

You can enable distraction-free writing mode using the icon to the right. This feature is not available for old browsers or devices with small screens, and requires that the full-height editor be enabled in Screen Options.

The Text mode allows you to enter HTML along with your post text. Note that paragraphs are converted to a empty line  when switching to the Text editor to make it less cluttered. When you type, a single line break can be used instead of typing shift-return, and two line breaks instead of paragraph tags. The line breaks are converted back to tags automatically.
Visual mode gives you an editor that is similar to a word processor.
This button expands the Visual mode's toolbar.

The Featured image for a post or page will be displayed in different ways depending on your theme.

It will be picked up automatically by twitter and other services if you share a link.

It can be used by the display post plugin to create visual navigation .
The Status can be set to Draft or Pending Review. It will automatically be set to Published when the post is published. This can be reverted.

Visibility includes options for password-protecting a post or making it stay at the top of your blog indefinitely (sticky). The Password protected option allows you to set an arbitrary password for each post. The Private option hides the post from everyone except editors and administrators.
Publish (immediately) allows you to set a future or past date and time, so you can schedule a post to be published in the future or backdate a post.

params.text:
Did you know there is another way to create content?

In the creating content section we show the classic WordPress editor.

In WordPress, the Block Editor and Classic Editor are two different tools that you can use to create and edit content for your website. The Classic Editor is a simpler and more straightforward tool that allows you to write and format content using a basic toolbar. It's ideal for beginners who don't need many advanced formatting options and just want to focus on writing and publishing their content.

On the other hand, the Block Editor is a more powerful and flexible tool that lets you create more complex content layouts using a block-based system. Each block represents a different element of your content, such as text, images, videos, or widgets, and you can easily move and customize them to create unique layouts. The Block Editor also offers a wide range of formatting options and customization features, which makes it a great choice for more experienced users or those who want more control over the look and feel of their content.

This book has been created in this site using the H5P plugin.

H5P allows content authors to create a wide range of interactive content types such as quizzes, interactive videos, interactive presentations, games, and more.

H5P content can be easily shared and reused, making it a powerful tool for collaboration and knowledge-sharing.
